meanings.definition: To make someone angry or irritated.
meanings.sent1: The loud noise from the construction site can madden the neighbors.
meanings.sent2: Her constant teasing started to madden him.
meanings.sent3: The mischievous puppy seemed to madden the old cat with its playful antics.
meanings.sent4: The never-ending traffic jam seemed to madden time itself.
meanings.sent5: The repetitive beeping of the alarm clock can madden even the most patient person.

meanings.sent1: I could feel myself start to madden as the customer continued to complain.
meanings.sent2: She tends to madden easily when things don't go her way.
meanings.sent3: The stubborn lock on the door seemed to madden him more than anything else.
meanings.sent4: The relentless heat of the sun can madden even the calmest person.
meanings.sent5: The constant buzzing of the fly started to madden him after a while.

meanings.definition: To drive someone crazy or insane.
meanings.sent1: The eerie silence in the abandoned house could madden anyone who dared to enter.
meanings.sent2: The mysterious disappearance of the key seemed to madden him beyond reason.
meanings.sent3: The confusing instructions on the manual threatened to madden the poor user.
meanings.sent4: The haunting melody of the music box seemed to madden the listener with its melancholic tune.
meanings.sent5: The never-ending maze of corridors could madden even the most experienced explorer.
